On the first day of school on Sept. 8, Irvington Union Free School District students logged into their classes remotely and virtually greeted their new teachers and classmates. Meanwhile, teachers warmly welcomed back their students, held get-to-know-you activities and presented their lessons from their empty classrooms.

“The opening days, despite being virtual, were still rich with great experiences that allowed students to get to know their teachers, reconnect with classmates and initiate essential learning experiences,” Superintendent of Schools Dr. Kristopher Harrison said.

In light of the coronavirus pandemic, K-12 students began the 2020-21 school year with distance learning before they return to their classrooms later this month for in-person instruction in a hybrid model. Over the last few months, administrators, Board of Education members and educators have been working diligently to prepare for the new school year and provide all students with a safe environment and high-quality learning experiences.

Dows Lane Welcomes Kindergartners to School

Dows Lane Elementary School welcomed its youngest students and their families during a special event on Aug. 20. Greeted by warm smiles, the incoming kindergartners arrived at school and safely took turns walking up to the front door and then back to their parents.

“It was an incredible day for our youngest learners to meet their teachers and see Dows Lane,” Principal Dr. Andrea Kantor said. “It gave them time to practice arriving at school, being dropped off and walking to the front door before the first day.”

Upon arrival, each kindergartner received a toy bulldog by PTSA vice presidents Karen Arnett, Sarah Harris-Weiss and Brittany Marcus. They were also greeted and escorted by Kantor, Assistant Principal Liza Greenspan and kindergarten teachers. Meanwhile, aides Sandy Cappello and Pat Motush helped with traffic flow and a first Bulldog welcome.

Students ‘Spread the Love’ With Hearts at Dows Lane

As students walk up to Dows Lane Elementary School, they are greeted by colorful chalk hearts that adorn the building’s walls.

“This ‘heart-attack’ represents our love for Dows Lane and love for learning,” Principal Andrea Kantor said. “When we have 100 by the end of the week, it will add to our 100th Day of School celebration on Feb. 14.”

Kantor said the students helped her decorate the school in hearts during their recess outside on Feb. 10. They also placed hearts on bulletin boards, doors and windows throughout the school. In addition, members of the third grade Student Council created an interactive “Spread the Love” wall display of jumbo hearts in the main lobby, where students can add their own paper heart with a message about something they love or share an act of kindness.

“We all miss our students and enjoyed seeing their smiling faces from a distance,” Main Street School Principal Joyce Chapnick said.

Palmieri was selected as one of the winners from a group of more than 15,000 finalists.

According to its website, the National Merit Scholarship Program honors students who show exceptional academic ability and potential for success in rigorous college studies.

Established in 1983, the National Hispanic Recognition Program identifies outstanding high school students with a minimum and regionally established PSAT score and a cumulative GPA of 3.5 by the middle of their junior year.

“We are incredibly proud that Chloe has been recognized as a National Hispanic Recognition Award recipient,” Principal Juliet Gevargis-Mizimakoski said.

Garcia’s school counselor Heather Attenello echoed the same sentiments and congratulated the student on her achievement.

“Chloe’s inner drive, motivation to succeed and desire to help others keep her focused in setting and achieving her goals,” Attenello said.

High School Students Create Enlarged Sculptures

Drawing inspiration from everyday objects, students in art teacher Kathleen Tetro’s Mixed Media/Sculpture class created larger-than-life sculptures out of recyclable materials, adhesive and paint.

As part of the project, the students used their math knowledge to recreate different objects, such as crayons, a vintage camera, LEGO pieces and mints, at a minimum of five times larger than the original size.

“The students worked at finding the correct dimensions of both geometric and organic objects, measuring the height, length, depth and angles to create accurate sketches,” Tetro said. “Then, they proceeded to multiply all dimensions by a specific number of their choosing to create an enlarged sculpture of the item.”

The project challenged the students to use their creativity, which yielded outstanding results.

“The crayons write, the Altoids box opens and although the camera cannot snap a picture, the inside of the lens is covered in mirror so the viewer can see themselves,” Tetro said.

Second Graders Bring Literature to Life

As part of the Bringing Literature to Life enrichment program, second graders have been working with theater educator Peter Royston. Under his guidance, they are collaborating and writing their own scripts to selected fables, which they will perform in front of an audience of peers, teachers and parents on March 31.

Throughout the experience, the students learn about the various tools that actors use to tell a compelling story, discover the power of theater and express their creativity through acting and playwriting.

The program directly aligns with the reading and writing units of study. It is funded through a generous grant by the Irvington Education Foundation.

Garcia Qualifies for State Track and Field Championship

Sarah Garcia, an Irvington High School senior and accomplished athlete, competed in the Section 1 New York State Indoor Track and Field qualifying meet, held at The Armory on Feb. 23. She finished second in the 1,500-meter race walk with a personal best of 7:28.19, qualifying for the state championship.

“Her breakthrough occurred this year after a summer of hard training and a successful cross-country season under the guidance of coach Chris Barry, who continued to train her during the winter season, while winter track co-coach Jim Buckley honed her technique,” coach Scott Mosenthal said.

(Note: pictured are wrestler Ian Schwam, who has earned the sectional championship title in the 145-pound weight class, runner Sarah Garcia and track coach Scott Mosenthal.)
